feed.title: SpellOnYou
feed.subtitle: Be afraid only of standing still. Remain fresh, body and soul.

entry.title: 5 reasons took much time to setting GPU for fast.ai than I expected

link.title: 5 reasons took much time to setting GPU for fast.ai than I expected

entry.content:
Motivation

Before now, me as a undergraduate student, I was parsimony who usually depend on colab, kaggle, friendâ€™s server(occasional) whenever i need GPU..Â  Â  And this time itâ€™s been for a while to install GPU than I expected and I share the several component that stood in my way.Â  Â  Written at Oct 24 2019, if you think this is deprecated, please do not have a leap of faith. Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 

1. Did not know there is JupyterLab in Google Cloud Platform.

At the first time when GCP came out, there was no AI Platform service. So from starting vm instance to launching jupyter and installing packages, I did all of the things myself. (but I learned ğŸ¤—)

$	curl -O https://repo.continuum.io/archive/Anaconda3-5.0.1-Linux-x86_64.sh

[Downloading conda in ssh]

Â  I created VM instance,selected zone, machine type and disk type. Then, define firewall rules and in ssh terminal, install jupyter and other packages.

But you can do all of these things AI Platform.

[AI Platform]

I think if you are at Asia-Pacific, it can save your time.

Â Â Â Â Â 

2. Consider if the platform has limited resources in a region you live in.

Â  I live in South Korea, East Asia, and it seems like this region has lots of limitation in GPU (except quite expensive AWS).

Â  And the Taiwan which was the only one region where I can launch my own VM with GPU (I tried all the other regions in the list) sometimes do normaly, but not always. ğŸ˜¥

Â  After launching, I did several works and next day I could not start VM. (I didnâ€™t count it, but tried it a few hours because I didnâ€™t want cost any more timeâ€¦)

Â  Endlessly failed to start instance, then I choose to move AWS as an alternative way.

Â Â Â Â Â 

3. Fast.ai gives deliberate guide and I didnâ€™t know it.

Â  Fast.ai offer the guide for all available platform. (Colab, salamander, Gradient, Kaggle, Colab, and so on)

Â  It is so important, and really needs, because cloud computing options are vary as occasion and purpose arise.

Â  I didnâ€™t know fast.ai has manual to running GCP, and I think itâ€™s as good a reason as any for me to be have taken time.

Â  It helped me so much when I had aws and shortened time.

Â Â Â Â Â 

4. You should wait to add more volume just after add volume, by building AWS EC2.

Â  Since Elastic Block Store(EBS) storage supports optimized storage, users canâ€™t extend storage volume two times in a row.

Â  Unfortunately, at the first time, I didnâ€™t know it (again ğŸ‘») and when VM lacked volume, I doubled dist capacity (76*2) at a rough but It needs more.

Â

entry.title: Lecture 08 - Deep Learning From Foundations
entry.content:
Â  I donâ€™t know if you read this article, but I heartily appreciate Rachael Thomas and Jeremy Howard for providing these priceless lectures for free Â  Contents Â  1) What is going on in this course 2) Library development using jupyter notebook Â  Resources

  • notebooks
  • material
  • video
  • broadcasting excel Â 

What is going on in this course?

Â 

What is â€˜from foundationsâ€™?

1) Recreate fast.ai and Pytorch

2) using pure python Â 

Evade Overfitting

Overfit : validation error getting worse ~training loss < validation loss~ Â 

Know the name of the symbol you use

find in this page if you donâ€™t know the symbol that you are using or just draw it here (run by ML!)

Steps to a basic modern CNN model

1) Matrix multiplication -> 2) Relu/Initialization -> 3) Fully-connected Forward -> 4) Fully-connected Backward -> 5) Train loop -> 6) Convolution-> 7) Optimization -> 8) Batchnormalization -> 9) Resnet

Todayâ€™s implementation goal: 1) matmul -> 4) FC backward

Â 

Library development using jupyter notebook

https://dbader.org/blog/python-assert-tutorial Â 

jupyter notebook certainly can make module

  • There will be #export tag that Howard (and we) want to extract
  • special notebook2script.py will detect sign of #expert and convert following into python module Â 
  • and test it

test\_eq(TEST,'test') test\_eq(TEST,'test1')

  • what is run_notebook.py?
    • when you want to test your module in command line interface

!python run\_notebook.py 01_matmul.ipynb

  • Is there any difference between 1) and 2)?

1) test -> test01 2) test01 -> test

#TODO I donâ€™t know yet

  • look into run_notebook.py, package fire Jeremy used. What is that?

read and run the code in a notebook, and in the process, Jeremy made Python Fire library called!shockingly, fire takes any kind of function and converts into CLI command.

fire library was released by Google open source, Thursday, March 2, 2017

Â 

01_matmul-(1).ipynb ends

01_matmul-(2).ipynb starts

Get data

  • pytorch and numpy are pretty much same.
  • variable c explains how many pixels there are in in MNIST, 28 pixels
  • PyTorchâ€™s view() method: torch function that manipulating tensor, and squeeze() in torch & mathmatical operation similar function
  • Rao & McMahan said usually this functions result in feature vector.
  • In part 1, you can use view function several times. Â 

Initial python model

  • Which is Linear, like $Xw$(weight)$+a$(bias) $= Y$

  • If you donâ€™t know hou to multiple matrix, refer this site matmul visulization site

How many time spends if we we use pure python

  • function matmul, typical matrix multiplication function, takes about 1 second for calculating 1 single train data! (maybe assumed stochastic, 5 data points in validation)

  • it takes about 11.36 hours to update parameters even single layer and 1 iteration! (if that was my computer, it would be 14 hours..)ğŸ¤ª

  • THIS is why we need to consider â€˜timeâ€™&â€™spaceâ€™

This is kinda slow - what if we could speed it up by 50,000 times? Letâ€™s try!

Â 

Elementwise ops

How can we make python faster?

  • If we want to calculate faster, then do remove pythonic calcuation, by passing its computation down to something that is written something other than python, like pytorch.
  • According to PyTorch doc it uses C++ (via ATen), so we are going to implement that function with python. Â 

What is element wise operation?

  • items makes a pair, operate corresponding component Â 

Frobenius norm

$ | A |F = \left( \sum{i,j=1}^n a_{ij} ^2 \right)^{1/2} $
  • above converted into

(m\*m).sum().sqrt()>

  • Plus, donâ€™t suffer from mathmatical symbols. He also copy and paste that equations from wikipedia.

  • and if you need latex form, download it from archive.
entry.summary: Â I donâ€™t know if you read this article, but I heartily appreciate Rachael Thomas and Jeremy Howard for providing these priceless lectures for free Â Contents Â 1) What is going on in this course 2) Library development using jupyter notebook Â Resources notebooks material video broadcasting excel Â
